fields.physical_description: The design has a scalloped edge and is almost the same as E.266-1973.  It is in darker ink, however, and is smudged as though water has been spilt on to it. The design is on a large, square sheet of thin paper.  There are pinholes beneath and in the border and also a few clusters above in the area of the design which depicts circles. There are no holes for pouncing.  The museum number is on the corner on the back of the border.  There are no watermarks in the paper.
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C, case T, shelf 184, box A
Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C

fields.name: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level C

fields.public_access_description:
This is a design for the border of a petticoat to a gown worn open to reveal the petticoat and thus known as an open gown. It is perhaps also for the border of  the gown, itself.  The design comes from a group of designs that were part of a retailer's archive which employed professional embroiderers. The names of the female clients inscribed on the designs were of the aristocracy, gentry or from wealthy families that moved in the upper reaches of society.  They had homes in the country and came to London for the season.  Retailers who sold such designs were linen drapers and lacemakers, both of which categories existed in London and were available to the clients. Many pattern drawers worked in London where their trade proved a lucrative business during the season. The similarity of some of the designs from this group to those by Styart, whose designs were published in London, does support the argument that these designs came from a retailer's archive based in London. 

The three fern-like stems could be three feathers emerging from a bow and resemble an aigrette which is an ornament in imitation of a plume of feathers.  This design is the same as another in the group (E.266-1973) which suggests that it might have been in demand by clients.  Perhaps the aigrette design was associated with the three plumes of feathers, symbol of the Prince of Wales.  This design might have been for Court dress.
fields.bibliography: Anchor Embroidery Stitches, <u>100 Embroidery Stitches</u>. J. & P. Coats (U.K.) Ltd., 1967. 6 p.
fields.history_note:
The designs were bequeathed to the Victoria and Albert Museum in 1973 by Raymond Johnes who had 'enormous and miscellaneous collections'.*  Johnes' collection included Japanese art, on which he published,** Indian and European material.  He did not specialise in collecting textiles although he owned some examples.  He was in contact with the Museum 1920s-1970 offering to sell objects from his collection.  Johnes did not provide the Museum with information about the history of ownership of the designs. 

*Mr B.W. Robinson, former Keeper of the Far Eastern Department, V&A, in a letter to Mr Ayres, Assistant- Keeper in the same Department, V&A Regsitry, nominal file, (MA/1/J479). 

**Johnes, Raymond. <u>Japanese Art</u> London: Spring Books, 1961. Conservation joined the two halves together in 2004.
fields.production_note:
The design comes from a group of designs that were part of a retailer's archive which employed professional embroiderers. The names of the female clients inscribed on the designs were of the aristocracy, gentry or from wealthy families that moved in the upper reaches of society.  They had homes in the country and came to London for the season.  Retailers who sold such designs were linen drapers and lacemakers, both of which categories existed in London and were available to the clients. Many pattern drawers worked in London where their trade proved a lucrative business during the season. The similarity of some of the designs from this group to those by Styart, whose designs were published in London, does support the argument that these designs came from a retailer's archive based in London.

Attribution note: The three fern-like stems could be three feathers emerging from a bow and resemble an aigrette or an ornament in imitation of a plume of feathers.  This design is the same as E.266-1973 which suggests that it might have been in demand by clients.  The clusters of pinholes suggest repeated use. The smudging may have been from watercolour and could be a result of tracing the design on to muslin or gauze by tacking the design underneath the textile and painting over the lines of the design with watercolour as described in <u>100 Embroidery Stitches</u>.  The position of the museum number suggests that the curator who numbered it thought that the feathers were at the bottom of the design.
fields.historical_context_note: Perhaps the aigrette design was associated with the three plumes of feathers, symbol of the Prince of Wales.  This design might have been for Court dress.  The size of the design and the type of border suggests a petticoat for an open gown and perhaps also for the border of the open gown, itself.
